region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will NEVER use brownie mix again since this recipe is super easy and even more tasty! Semisweet chips definitely give a depth of flavor you just can't get from cocoa powder. Be sure to use quality chocolate chips to ensure the best chocolate flavor. Also, you might want to temper the eggs before adding them to the warm chocolate mixture or allow the chocolate mixture to cool a bit so you don't end up with scrambled eggs in the batter. I used a 16 ounce bag of chocolate chips, melting the 1 1/2 cups as the recipe calls for and adding the extra 1/2 cup to the cooled batter so I could have chocolate chunks in the brownies.  (If you do add the extra chocolate chips, toss them in a teaspoon of flour to coat them so they won't sink to the bottom of the pan.) Thanks for sharing this recipe. I'll be making these brownies again and again!

text:
I'm very impressed. In fact, I have to go change my review of another brownie recipe because this one is absolutely the best (and I can't say that about the other recipe anymore). Tastes just like the brownies out of a box. I followed the recipe exactly, baked for 25 minutes, and they are perfect. I have to hurry and freeze them so I don't eat them all in one sitting. Next time, I will omit the salt, but that is the only modification I will make. Except doubling or tripling this recipe! Worth the hype. This will now be my brownie recipe of choice. Excellent! *update: these are just as delicious after being frozen! I defrosted at room temperature in a sandwich bag. Still delicious! *update 2: I have also made these as mini cupcakes. In the oven for 7 minutes makes them just cooked enough. Yum, yum, yum! Huge hit at a recent party!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
MMMMM...Delicious!!! These brownies are rich, chocolatey, and absolutely fabulous! I mean to try to describe these brownies using just one word may be virtually impossible, just as impossible as it is to eat just one of these. If you LOVE chocolate, then this is the brownie for you! Definitely have a tall glasss of ice cold milk on hand, 'cause you're gonna need it! I substituted 2 Tbsp. of coffee liqueur for the water and since a bag of Hershey's chocolate chips is 2 cups I took the other 1/2 cup and tossed those into the batter before baking - I mean you can never have too much chocolate. I baked them for 30 minutes in an 8x8 glass pan sprayed with Pam for baking. I highly recommend rinsing/wiping down your knife between each slice when cutting your brownies so you get nice slices. I topped them off with a dusting of confectioners' sugar and next time I might add in some chopped walnuts. These are a must try for all the brownie lover's out there!

text:
WOW!!! Are you kidding me? These are definitely the best brownies I've ever had. I was really craving brownies, but was out of cocoa powder, so I wanted a recipe that didn't require it. These brownies definitely hit the spot...I ate so much, I went to work out afterwards! The use of chocolate chips in this recipe make the chocolate taste more "chocolatey" if you will. It is very rich and better than any store bought I know of...I feel less guilty about eating these than the boxed mixes that have additives, preservatives, and hydrogenated oils. These brownies are killer. One thing though...I baked mine for more than the recommended time. I was concerned about doing this because the recipe stresses not to overbake the brownies, but I guess it varies by oven. I used the toothpick test and it did not come out clean, so I baked for about another 12 to 15 minutes. The edges were just crispy and the middle was just done, almost fudgy..... Also, I didn't have an 8x8 pan, but I wanted brownies so bad that I used a round dish (not even a pan, a dish!). But it didn't matter. YYYUUUUMMM!!! Try these...you won't be disappointed. Thanks for sharing this one. It's a keeper.

text:
I've never made brownies with melted chocolate chips before so I was very curious, however, with so many reviewers pleased with this recipe I felt confident I wouldn't be disappointed - and I wasn't. I used Ghiradelli chocolate chips and reduced the salt to 1/4 tsp.  As the submitter warns, don't overbake and you'll be rewarded with rich, fudgy brownies.  Great as is, but I topped mine with Brownie Frosting, recipe also from this site.

text:
These brownies could have been made from a mix. They had the flakey top layer that you get from a mix, the great chewy crust pieces, and an awesome deep dark fudgey chocolate flavor. I don't need to buy brownies from a box anymore. 
*edit*
I wanted to try a PB/Chocolate brownie so I used half PB chips and half chocolate chips in this recipe. The verdict? If you want peanut butter chocolate brownies, marble some PB into the tops of this recipe using the full amount of chocolate chips.

text:
I used irish cream for water & I did only bake for 25 minutes. While they were baking, I heated 1/3 cup of Irish cream to boiling & added 8 oz of chopped white chocolate, stirring until it melted. Letting it sit to cool before pouring/spreading on the cooled brownies. I let them set up in the fridge before slicing. They were good but I thought they needed more butter. Thanks for the recipe!

None
text:
The great thing about this recipe is that if you like gooey brownies, when baked for around 25 mins, the melted chocolate with ensure they are gooey!  If you prefer them cake-y, you can cook for longer & they will cake up.  Brilliant, no?!  They also have that beautiful glossy top & chewy edges :)
I really recommend letting the melted chocolate mix cool a minute or two before whisking the egg in, just to avoid cooking any of the egg.  
...Oh, and I also love that everything in this recipe is a real ingredient, no prepackaged mixes - no ingredients list that sounds like a laboratory inventory!  Chocolate happiness, no?!

text:
My hubby had a craving for brownies so I decided to make this recipe because it looked easy.  What a surprise!!  Fabulous taste (melt in your mouth) perfect texture and not overly sweet.  I am not a fan of brownies, but I couldn’t stop eating these!  Hubby gave them 2 thumbs up and said they were the best brownies he had ever tasted.  I didn't modify the recipe at all and won't when i make them again--it's perfect.  I baked them for 25 minutes in an 8 x 8 pan and i think that 30 minutes would have dried them out.  The toothpick test does not work for brownies, so i checked to see if brownies were pulling away from the sides of pan (slightly) This is definitely a repeat!

text:
These are awesome brownies.  I played with the recipe a bit to combat the cake-like quality of the brownies that some reviewers complained about, and found that using only 1 egg makes them much more fudge-like.  Would be 5 stars for me with this change.  
Also, I reserved about 1/3 cup of the chocolate chips to sprinkle on top before baking.  Yum!

text:
Great recipe, but I have to admit I was hesitant at first when I added the chocolate chips into the water/butter/sugar mixture. I was worried my chocolate would seize and when it was looking too pasty I transferred the chocolate mixture to my Kitchen-Aid bowl and began blending it together really well which helped as I added the vanilla and eggs. I baked this in my springform pan for 22 minutes. Makes a great cakey brownie!

country:

text:
I made this particular brownie recipe because I had everything in stock. I used Nestle's semi sweet morsels and followed the recipe except I tried the first review's suggestion of mixing another half cup of morsels in flour for chunks of chocolate in the brownies. Well I guess my mixture was still too warm and they melted anyway. That said, these brownies were perfect...not too cakey, and not too fudgey. Our guest cleaned the dish spotless. I baked them in an 8X8 glass Pyrex for exactly 25 minutes. They held together very well and weren't crumbly like a lot of brownies, very moist and no need for anything extra like frosting...they were sweet enough and thick enough as they are. I think I'll just add 2 cups of morsels next time I make them instead of 1 1/2 cups to achieve the exact brownie texture...and I will make these again and again.

text:
Yummy! These brownies were so good and almost perfect. Mine had to cook for 35 minutes instead of 25-30. But the main thing - too much salt! And I did measure it out. I usually don't, but this time I did and made sure it was 1/2 tsp. Each bite I took it was like, "Wow this is good, but there is that hint of salt at the end". I didn't like that and I am suprised that it happened. Next time, if I am using salted butter, I will not use any salt. Otherwise - awesome brownies. This will definitely be my new "Go to" recipe. Thanks!

userID:
10030017
Display Name:
akbigmac
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
8
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/897097.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I tried this recipe I had to cook it for 40 min. till the middle was cooked, and it came out kinda flat and VERY salty, and  I could barely choke it down!!!( my chocolate loving brother didn't care though and ate 1/4 of it ) I was like what did I do wrong??? I went back to the recipe and I saw I added half of a TABLEspoon instead of half a teaspoon, I ended up throwing almost the whole thing away!!! ADVICE : MAKE SURE YOU PUT IN THE RIGHT AMOUNT OF SALT !!! I tried it again the next day adding the right amount of salt( actually a little less ) I also waited a couple minutes for the sugar/water/butter/chocolate mix to cool so the eggs wouldn't start to cook in the mixture. The brownies didn't come out flat,like before and only needed to be cooked for 25 min. After waiting around 15 min. for them to cool, I cut them and they were a little cakey, just a little. They WERE good, I just prefer a brownie that's more fudgey. But the rest of my famiglia LOVED them. It really just depends on what kind of brownie you like.
So in conclusion:
-Add the right amount of salt in (maybe a little less)
-let the sugar/chocolate/water/butter mixture cool a little before putting the eggs in
-let the brownies cool before cutting them
And you will get a perfectly good moist cakeish brownie !!!
*** update ***
I think if you cook the brownies a little shorter, say 20 min., they will turn out more fudgy

Easy peasy. I told my fiancée I was going to make brownies from scratch and she seemed a little skeptical of the potential outcome. Well she loved these. I like them too. One not of caution, they came out a little gooey (which is fine) but I got a little anxious and cut them way too soon. Definitely wait until they get a chance to cool properly and they will set up nice so you can cut and serve easier.

text:
These brownies were absolutely "mmmmmm".  I made them in a mini muffin tin, cooked for about 10 minutes (I might cook them for a little longer next time.  They were a little too soft in the middle).  The batter made 24 good sized brownie bites.  A bag of chocolate chips is 2 cups.  I thought more has to be better.  Next time I'll stick with the recipe.  It was hard to mix and it turned into a big fudgie ball.  After all was said and done it wasn't a problem but next time I'll just do it as it is suggested.  I found mint Hershey's kisses (for St.Patricks day).  I put one on each brownie bite.  I can't tell you how good that made them!  Tasted just like a thin mint Girl Scout cookie.  Yum!

text:
Tastes great, part fudgy part cakey. I had no problems with the falling in the middle, they cooked up just right in 25 minutes. Made to the recipe after some discussion on the RE about the chips lumping/seizing up when added in. The sugar mix did not liquify for me by just bringing to a boil, and when the chips are added it all just lumped together. I added the eggs and and stirred till my shoulders ached and it finally smoothed out. Added dry mix in and spread in pan and baked. They do taste good! I might try microwaving the first steps the next time. Because the end result was good I'm rating it for 5 stars. Thanks for the recipe!

1 cup sugar
4 tbs butter
4 tbs water
3 cups semisweet chocolate chips
4 eggs 
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1 1/3 cup flour
2- 1/4 teaspoons baking soda
1 teaspoon salt

Perfect for my 9x13 pan
baked for 30 minutes 
did check frequently with a toothpick.

Great recipe! Thank you for sharing!

text:
This recipe is very simple and delicious! I doubled the recipe and put it in a 9x13 glass pan and cooked them for 28 minutes. I put extra mini chocolate chips in the batter once it was completed and beat the eggs before adding them to the chocolate chips and butter. I had no problems with the eggs scrambling since I waited a couple minutes after stirring in the chocolate. I put chocolate frosting on top and they vanished! Will definitely make again!!!

text:
Yummmm! These brownies turned out great even with the two changes I made. I used whole wheat pastry flour instead of all purpose because thats the only flour I had, and I also used evaporated cane juice in place of the white sugar. So it made them a bit healthier and you could not tell what-so-ever that they were whole wheat. I followed the rest of the recipe exactly and baked for 25 minutes and they came out perfect! They smelled so good that I couldn't resist cutting into them, but it was cakey and fell apart. I waited until they cooled completely and by then they were fudgy, slightly chewy, with a rich chocolatey flavor and not too sweet, which I love! This will be my go-to brownie recipe from now on!

When I saw these awesome brownie pictures I thought I just had to try them! I liked the fact that they contain chocolate chips instead of cocoa. dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
2
userID:
14375031
Display Name:
Amnip
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
27
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making brownies from scratch. I found the recipe to be extremely simple to follow and super delicious. I used 1 cup of milk chocolate chips and 1/2 cup of butterscotch chips. Instead of mixing them in the pot with my water sugar butter mix, I poured the molten mixture in the bowl with my chips and melted it that way... In my haste, I forgot that I had gotten the chips straight from the freezer, so the mixture turned all nougat-y and weird. I set my bowl in some hot (nearly boiling) water and mixed until the chocolate became smooth, then I added my eggs (room temperature) one by one and followed the rest of the steps exactly (cept I also used baking powder [3/4tsp] instead of soda) as they were written. Put them in the oven for 27.5 mins, let them cool in the freezer, and voila.. Rich, moist, soft, and fudgey. Super yum... Even with a rough start.

text:
A few notes first...
You are NOT NOT NOT supposed to do the toothpick test with these brownies. I made that mistake at 25mins in. Toothpick came out with lots of wetness n it. Baked 5 more minutes and did it again and realized that this is how these brownies are supposed to be. With SO much melted chocolate in it, it would be impossible to determine doneness by the toothpick test. 
Follow the times given in the recipe and you will have a delicious gooey rich brownie!
I will never buy box brownie mix again. these were AWESOME and would be perfect for Hot fudge cake sundae or just a plain ole scoop of vanilla ice cream. I can't praise these enough!

text:
I usually never write reviews but these were so incredible I felt compelled. I made these for a Mother's day party and everyone who ate them stated "best brownies ever!" I doubled the recipe and baked @ 325 in a 9"x13" metal pan for 45 minutes. I used a 24 ounce bag of chips (3 measured cups melted in as described, the rest I dumped in at the very end.) I also added 1 3/4  cups of chopped walnuts (roughly 1 1/2 cups in mix, the remainder sprinkled on top) which turned out to be a really nice touch. So simple and so delicious, I will NEVER use a mix again!

text:
I have been searching for a "go-to" brownie recipe for the last year. (My favorite mix -Martha White Chewy Fudge- was discontinued).  I have tried so many mixes and recipes only to be disappointed in the flavor or texture.... UNTIL NOW!!!  I followed this recipe exactly and they had the perfect flavor.  (I took them out at 25 minutes exactly.)  I may try using brown sugar next time to see if I can make them just a little chewier.  I do not like cakey brownies at ALL, so I wouldn't say these were like cake... I just wouldn't mind them being just a little chewier.

text:
Yes, this recipe is definitely easy and yummy as-is. 
I use about 2/3 c all purpose white flour and 1/3 c whole wheat flour, about 1/2 c pecans, plus a beet that is ground up in a blender. I also test mine for done-ness by sticking a knife in it to see if it comes out clean and en up baking it for ~35 minutes. 
I gotta say that the beet is a really nice addition :)

text:
I'm not a big dessert person, so I was a little apprehensive about making brownies from scratch for the first time, especially because I had to eyeball all the measurements. It was unbelievably easy & painless, requiring few ingredients that you wouldn't already have in your kitchen. They turned out amazingly. There's a thin crusty layer on top, soft and fudgy underneath. Best of all, people are very impressed that these are from scratch, even though they're just as easy as going the boxed route.

text:
I would have to respectfully disagree with the reviewer who wrote that these brownies are as good as the ones out of a box; these are so so so much better! After a long day of wrangling sick fussy kids, I was in desperate need of some chocolate therapy and these brownies were just what the doctor ordered. I used a 12 oz. bag of semisweet chocolate chips and then tossed about 1/2 cup of milk chocolate chips in with the flour. These brownies are like little bites of fudge. I had to give half of them away so I wouldn't eat them all.

text:
If you like melt in your mouth, fudgy brownies then this is by far the best recipe you will find! I will say that once they're done baking you have to have a little bit of patience, though. I wanted to cut them up and eat them after 5 minutes, but they need MUCH more time to cool down. I'd say give them at least 30 minutes to cool down before trying to cut them up. Otherwise they will just fall apart on you. Either way, they're delicious!

I agree with others, dark/bittersweet chocolate is not best to add in my opinion. Semisweet worked great. I also added a couple tablespoons of cocoa, and tablespoon Agave  Great recipe all in all!

This is now my 'go to' brownie recipe!  Turned out perfect in every way.  I also greased the pan with coconut oil.  These brownies are the BEST I've ever had.

text:
I live in South Korea, so I have very limited options when it comes to baking unless I order things online.  I was able to find everything in this recipe here, so I gave it a try.  However, because Koreans aren't big on baking, I have only a toaster oven.  The cooking time was a LOT longer in a toaster oven.  Also, I had to use the only chocolate I could find, but the taste seems okay.  I also had to use I Can't Believe It's Not Butter and a tinfoil baking pan.
Overall, I liked them a lot.  They were very comparable to a mix, and very very simple.  If you have to make due with what you have when things are very limited, I would suggest these!

text:
These brownies were not only quick and easy to prepare, but fun to bake! Thou I am not a chocolate, fudge kind of person I wanted to make this for my family as a special treat. Once the melted chocolate chips were cooled, I mixed in the eggs and vanilla, then the  flour mixture. I also added an extra 1/2 cup of chocolate chips that I lightly dusted with flour to help them stay afloat in the brownies. I sprayed the 8X8 pan with PAM then I baked these at 325 degrees for approximately 25 minutes, and took them out to cool. I wanted these to be a nice, rich, fudgy brownie. I also wanted to decorate these with frosting - and a big thanks to Naples34102 for mentioning, "Brownie Frosting." The results? Family says, "Mmmm...so ONO (delicious)." I was told the brownies were delicious, moist chocolately, rich and they liked the bits of chocolate chips in the brownies.

text:
These are SOOOO good! I prefer fudgy brownies over cake-like ones, so these are right up my alley. I've made them twice now, doubling the recipe and baking them in a 9x13 pan. This recipe is so much easier than my usual homemade brownie recipe, but tastes just as good, if not better. I think my oven was running hotter than the set temperature the first time I made them, and the brownies puffed up all around the edges but stayed sunken in the center. They still tasted great, but the next time I used an oven thermometer and adjusted the oven temp so it read correctly and the result was much better.

text:
anxiously waiting for the brownies to bake, cool and be cut up so I can devour them.  Loved the ease of this recipe, esp after I made it easier on myself (and my 7 y/o) by nuking the butter, water, sugar and chocolate step instead of using the stove.  Just microwaved the butter, water, and sugar for 1 min (or however long it takes to get water hot in your micro) then dump chocolate chips  in, stir and nuke for 30 sec intervals and stir until melted and smooth.  Also loved that this recipe didn't use a dozen eggs and an entire stick and a half of butter.  Good grief, I want a brownie, not another love handle and a splitting headache.  Thanks cicada77.  So far, so good.

text:
Before baking these brownies I read some of the 5 star ratings as well as the 1, 2, and no stars.  Those who did not rate this recipe highly talked of cakiness, bland flavor, or the batter sinking in the oven. I used Nestle toll house morsels and followed the directions and am now eating fudgy, chocolatey brownies that are not cake-like at all and have great texture. I can only guess that those who did not like the recipe either used poor quality ingredients, generic chips, or perhaps they were at a higher altitude?  These are the best homemade brownies I have ever made and I have tried more than a few!

These cookies were fabulous!  I baked for 30 mins and they came out very moist.  I mixed the eggs and vanilla in a separate bowl, then added the brownie mixture from the saucepan to the bowl.  I also added the flour, baking soda and salt in the bowl with some walnuts.  The steps were simple, a bit more cleanup for me, but I think it was worth it.   I know I'll be making these in the future. Thanks.

text:
Followed the recipe the the letter, if I was blinded, I could easily have believed they were crispy bites of cake. I baked them in a 9x9 glass pan. They fell big time in the middle, leaving me with a very thin chewy cake, and an outside that was as hard as a rock. Very little chocolate taste, and I had read other reviews and used milk chocolate chips. They were hard to mix at first, but eventually they came together and the batter was very easy to work with. Once they cooled, they were hard as a rock. Sorry, but i will have to keep on looking. Thanks anyhow.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
wonderful!!  I have made brownies from scratch for many years but this recipe is by far the best and easiest of all;  perfect the way it is - no changes needed.  Not a better tasting brownie out there!  I doubled the recipe the 2nd time and put in a 11x7 pan - cooked for about 37 minutes which made for a really thick brownie.  Believe me when I say a single recipe is not enough!!  Some reviewers mentioned the thick batter being hard to stir - I think this is from letting the water/sugar/butter mixture simmer too long causing some of the liquid to evaporate - when this happens just add another tablespoon of butter or two  to the mixture before adding the eggs and dry ingredients.   Our family likes their brownies frosted - so while the brownies are still warm I put a thick layer of good old fashioned chocolate frosting on - this way it kinda melts into the brownies and makes them even better.  Also want to mention there is a similar named brownie on this site so don't be confused - just copy this one to your recipe box. You won't want to lose this recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were pretty good, but not the best. Even though they are moist, they are not as chewy as I would like. They were extremely heavy and dense, which makes you soooo constantly thirsty aterwards, no matter how much you drink!! I loved the taste, but a little too heavy and stick to the roof of your mouth cuz they're so dense. All in all, nice and chocolatey, and perfect if you like thick and dense! thanks!...UPDATE: 
Made these again, using the right kind of chocolate and this does a world of a difference!! I had used 70% cocoa the first time, and the consistency was extremely heavy, and so different when using the semi-sweet chocolate chips!! Even though they seem underdone after the amount of time written, make sure to not over cook. I added about 10 minutes to it, and still felt ndercooked, but I took them out anyway. After cooling, you realize that they are perfect that way, so chewy and delicious! My guests couldn't believe how good these were, and asked for the recipe!! I did put a layer of chocolate bar (such as caramilk) in between two layers of dough, which made these extra special!!

text:
Using semi-sweet chips is key! I tried dark chocolate and it just didn't come out the same. For even extra richness I made some peanut butter topping by putting about 1/2 c. into a bowl and microwaving until soft and pliable. I then added 2 tbsp. of powdered sugar, for texture after done baking. SOOOO good and rich and moist and and and.... You will definitely need a cup of milk for those.

This recipe is simply great! I don't see how you could go wrong! It is so simple & so delicious!!! If you only try one recipe on this site, this should be the one. I prepared the brownies exactly as written, baking them for only 25 minutes in a glass pan. They did appear a bit cakey at first, however, after cooling they were perfect -even better the next day! photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/151940.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fantastic!!  I've made them twice now, and they are seriously the best brownies I have ever had.  The first time I used whole grain pastry flour, doubled the vanilla, and did everything else the by the recipe.  The second time I used regular whole wheat flour, doubled the vanilla and used half of the salt.  I think that 1/2 a tsp is more than necessary.  They raised just fine, and were fabulous both times, but better the second.  Oh yeah, and these were meant to be made with walnuts.  I did some with and some without, and the ones with were perfect!  I don't mix the walnuts in the batter, I just sprinkle them (liberally) on top, and lightly press them into the batter.  You want them to be sticking out so that they get roasted.  Thanks for the awesome recipe!!

text:
this is truly a wonderful brownie recipe-i've been using one very very close to this one for years, and ALWAYS get rave reviews about 'em.  the only difference in my recipe is, that you only put half the chocolate chips into the sugar/butter/water after boiling along with the vanilla; then after you've stirred&gotten the chips melted smooth, added the eggs(one at a time)and the flour mixture, put in the rest of the chips&can add nuts too, if desired. this makes the chips sort of "stand alone" during&after the baking process. you get yummy munches of chocolate chips when you're eating brownie!  :) excellent recipe.

text:
We've been making these for a few weeks now and I will never go back to box. We doubled the recipe and added a 24 oz. bag of semi-sweet chocolate chips. It is about a cup more than needed but well worth it. Buttered a 9x13 pan and baked for the same amount of time. They always come out with the top flakey with just a tad of crisp. There's no hard, over baked sides with these brownies either. Just moist and fudgy. perfect for that tie you over snack. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This is AMAZING and so easy to make! I love this recipe because the brownies are so fudgy and dense, the best texture I think brownies should have. The flavour is rich and deep too! Everyone LOVES this recipe. One thing I would recommend is that when you are adding the eggs to the chocolate-sugar-butter mixture, you should let the chocolate mixture cool down slightly before adding the eggs, so they don’t cook. My first time making them, I didn’t wait, and the eggs actually cooked and I found bits of scrambled, cooked egg in my brownie! We still liked them though. This recipe is amazing!!

text:
LOVE IT.  The top is nice and flaky, it has the moist texture but isn't airy or spongey like a cake as long as you don't over bake.  One alteration I made was that I left out 1/4 cups of the chocolate chips and added it last after the flour mixture.  This way, when you bite into it, you can still taste bits of the chocolate whether it's still warm or cooled, which makes it extra interesting.

text:
These are THE BEST brownies... EVERRRR! For real. We did exactly what the recipe called for. We did use a user suggestion to have the eggs at room temperature. So I just sat the eggs out for about an hour before I started. Wow. One suggestion I do have... double the recipe. These go quickly and you will wish you had more. You can put any leftovers you cant finish in the freezer. Just take them out and thaw them and you can zap them in the microwave or oven for a few minutes (seconds if in micro) and it will taste just as great. I cannot wait to bring these tasty treats to dinner parties and get-togethers! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I added an indeterminate amount of walnuts to the batter and on top just prior to baking. Also, I hand stirred with a whisk, adding the eggs one at a time. If you're baking in a darker pan, either lower the temperature 25 degrees, or bake for less time. These are amazing, and very chocolatey.

text:
It took me so long to find a brownie recipe that wasn't cake like. These were perfect. I did double the recipe for my 9x13 pan and baked them for 30 minutes on 325 degrees.  I also tossed some mini m&ms in a couple tablespoons of flour and added them to the mixture for some extra flavor.  I also made a homemade frosting, recipe is 1 stick of softened butter, beat on low speed for 30 seconds to 1 minute, add 3 or 4 cups of powdered sugar, 1 tablespoon of vanilla and 3 or 4 tablespoons of milk.  If you want a thicker frosting add a little more powdered sugar and if you want it thinner then add a little more milk, and if you want more flavor then add a touch more vanilla.

Delicious!  Just what I was looking for, the only problem is it's not enough!  Definitely need to double the recipe, these were gone in our house in one day.  We are trying to eat as GMO free as possible and therefore not buying processed snacks & desserts.  Making my own desserts with (mostly) organic ingredients and these were perfect.  They did have a slightly salty taste, which I actually loved.  It may be due to the fact that I didn't have quite enough choc chips, had about 1.25 c instead of 1.5.  I will see how they come out when I make with the 1.5 c next and decide which I like best, but will definitely be making again, the consistency was between cakey and chewy, just perfect.  May also like to try with nuts. I also used salted butter, so may cut out the added salt also.

country:
None
text:
My word these really are so yummy... I doubled the amount as I was taking them to a friends birthday however my family tested them and nearly ate them all so I have had to make another batch... I almost followed the recipe given but added double the vanilla as I make my own which is lovely. I also added 200g of chopped Pecan nuts and the chocolate I used was half milk and half plain plus 2 tablespoons of coco powder. I took the butter, sugar and water off the heat and left to cool for 5 minutes then added the chocolate to melt before adding the egg and vanilla. Turned out moist with a soft chewy center. Will 100% be making them again as they were a hit with everyone. Easy to make just don't over mix or they will turn out spongy. Don't over cook either or will go hard and dry.. I only left them in the oven for 25 mins and were ready..Also if you can wait that long leave them to cool in the tray for as long as possible which keeps them moist. Satisfaction all round... Thanks for a lovely recipe Nicola

text:
These are amazing!!  I have made these a couple times and will never buy boxed brownie mix again.  When I first made them, I followed the recipe as written and it was not chocolaty enough and too salty (unless you're going for something sweet and salty).
Now when i make these I cut the salt in half, use a whole bag of semi-sweet Ghiradelli chocolate chips and add 1/2 cup chopped walnuts and they are amazing!  I find the better brand chocolate chips (ghiradelli vs the store brand) make the brownies taste better too!

text:
Extremely simple to make, only uses one pan to cook all ingredients in, and one pan to bake it in. Used glass baking pan; brownies' outcome were soft, very moist, very chocolatey, but still had that cake look--not the fudgy look some end up. I allowed the brownies to cool off in pan as instructed, this allows the product to have continuous cooking while pan's heat gradually decreases. Such an elegant recipe with such simplicity. Absolutely exquisite! Very easy to make, I say again, because I have a one-year-old constantly nagging me while I cook, and I need that fast bake-off. Thank you sooooo much! These are DELICIOUS! I will NEVER use any other recipe except this one ever again!!!

I doubled the recipe and sent some to work with my husband. Cooks Illustrated has a chewy brownie recipe that comes out SO much more delicious but they aren't as pretty and it's a fairly complicated recipe. But as for these, I would definitely make them again. BUT use mexican vanilla, or madagascar vanilla. It makes a brownie 10X better!

userID:

Display Name:
Phillyfoodie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy to make and the best brownies I've ever had. In half a day I ate almost the whole batch just by nibbling here and there, sadly for my waistline. I only gave 4 stars because the 1/2 tsp of salt will make these taste like they were marinated in the ocean. I added less than a 1/4 tsp and it still tasted a bit too salty, but not enough to ruin them. I would add a "pinch" for depth of flavor but that's all. I also used Hershey's chips which made them even darker and richer tasting. I saved a few and coated them in cocoa and stirred them into the batter for chunks of chocolate, but next time I'm going to leave them out. These are so rich and delicious they don't need any extras. The outside is nice and caramelized and the inside is moist and melty. This is my go to recipe for brownies from now on.

text:
Why you'd want to buy another boxed brownie rather than making this your go-to recipe is beyond me! These ingredients are always on hand here and rather than experiencing a convenient way to make brownies at home with a boxed variety, you get to experience the satisfaction of a (quick and simple) recipe that has you heating, stirring, measuring, and enjoying brownies a la made-from-scratch, which is how I prefer it. Prior to giving this recipe a whirl, I had found Ghiradelli's boxed brownies to be our family's favorite, but this recipe is absolutely what makes the perfect brownie, in my book, hence the 5 stars. *I will say that I used a butter pat to grease my pan since it was already out and since it was salted butter, the outer brownies came with a bit more saltiness that I wasn't expecting, but that I loved! Sweet and salty, how could that go wrong?! So, just for those that may use the same method to prepare a pan but have salt sensitivity, try unsalted butter. I also do not like iced brownies, so these were naked and chocolatey all on their own. Next time, I'm going to experiment with adding chopped candy bars on top or toffee crunch. You can really expand on this recipe easily. Try it!

5

text:
So easy and so GOOD!  I always keep a couple of boxes of brownie mix in the cupboard, for those times I need to throw something together really quick.  Today was one of those times, but oops, I forgot to restock my pantry.  However it was stocked with chocolate chips.  These were so simple, and the use of chocolate chips instead of cocoa powder makes them so much fudgier than other scratch brownies.  This will be my new go to recipe whenever I want something beyond the generic taste the box mixes create.  I added a dash of cinnamon with the dry ingredients, and 1/2 cup chocolate chips to the batter.  Two things I always do with box mixes, and voila!  Yummy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/536161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Took me awhile to get this one right, it seemed that no matter what I did the cooking time wasn't right, it turned out either gooey or hard, I solved this by cooking it for the longer listed time and tested with a toothpick every 30 seconds thereafter until it came out almost dry. Then I had a problem with it sticking no matter how I prepared the pan or no matter how much time I let the Brownies cool in the pan, I finally solved this by lining the pan with parchment paper, slitting the corners so that the paper fit down into the pan. After all of this and finding a good frosting to go with the intense chocolate flavor of the brownies (I ended up using a sour cream chocolate frosting, light on the chocolate) my grandkids like it so much they want me to make them a new batch every week. They won't even eat boxed mix brownies any more, well they won't eat them without complaining about how much better Grandpa's are anyway.

I have been trying tons of different brownie recipes.  My husband likes boxed, but I don't like the extra preservatives and wanted to be able to make some from scratch.  Most I made dried out horribly the next day and just weren't very flavorful.  These were gooey and moist and didn't dry out.  Granted they didn't last past the second day, but still. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/926498.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm going to have to make these again sometime to give a fair review. I underbaked them by quite a bit somehow and wound up with delicious goo, kind of like a pudding cake. We'll eat the goo, and it is delicious goo, so I cannot give this less than 5 stars, as the fault for underbaking is my own! P.S. Some of the method is goofy here. Beat your eggs & vanilla together before you add them; trying to beat your eggs into the chocolate mixture is a fool's errand! Also, add the vanilla after the eggs (or beat them together). If you add the vanilla before the eggs you'll seize the chocolate; chocolate needs a LOT of liquid at once to not seize (or none at all); just a little liquid will ruin it! Thanks for the recipe!

Excellent recipe.  Very simple, easy to make and every bit as good as a store box mix for a much lower price.  I was looking for a good made-from-scratch brownie recipe that doesn't use 1C of butter and this is certainly it.  If you don't like them as thick, use a 9x13 pan instead.  Can also increase eggs to 3 for a more cakelike result.

text:
I often read recipes and wonder how a few people can rate something as bad, when 99.9 percent of ratings are so good? Maybe I didn't bake these long enough, but at 25 minutes ("do not overbake") I took them out. Should have gone 30 minutes. The edges have a good taste but the brownie looks 'wet' and undercooked. I also had to use a power mixer to put the ingredients together, as the chocolate turned to a thick fudge once melted, and wouldn't blend into the eggs too well. Unlikely I'll attempt this one again. Good luck to the others.

text:
I really liked this recipe. I would have given this 4 stars but my husband insists that these are the best brownies he's ever had. Here are some road blocks I ran in to. First,the batter got so thick when I added the chocolate that I couldn't mix it by hand. I got out my hand mixer and all was well. Also, it took quite a bit longer than the 25-30 min. at 325 for mine. With the do not over bake warning, I was scared to push it past 30 min. but I kept on and got almost done brownies at about 35 min. They are still a little undercooked but I like 'em that way! I served the brownies over a vanilla bean custard sauce and topped with nuts, ice cream, and caramel. Delish!

These brownies were very easy to make and so delicious they didn't last 24hrs!  I only had a 150g bar of 70% cocoa chocolate so I grated it and melted it in as per the recipe.  After pouring the batter into the baking pan I also swirled in some melted white chocolate to make up for the lack of dark chocolate.  Looked, smelled and tasted amazing - a great hit with the children and even the husband who's not a sweet fan.  Will definitely be baking these again soon!

text:
Good flavor...I didn't have great results but that is my fault, I live in high altitude and spaced adding the extra flour, I remembered to decrease the soda...so my brownies came out flat. So next time i will definitely remember to add it...lol *UPDATE* Ok so I retried this recipe but remembered to do all of the adjustments for high altitude. I added 1 Tbsp flour, 1 Tbsp water, reduced the baking soda by 1/8 tsp. Came out perfect! The flavor last time was great but they came out flat, this time they are tastey AND plump!

text:
This is an excellent basic brownie recipe. We like our brownies more gooey and less cakey... this recipe says to cook for 25-30 minutes. I cooked these for 19 minutes and they were completely done. In fact, we would've preferred even gooier. That could just be our oven, but if you don't like brownies that are very cake-like, just make sure to undercook these just a tad. They're even better the second day!

text:
This was my first time making brownies, and I followed the recipe almost exactly. They turned out lovely! Crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. However, but that's just a personal opinion, I would've liked the brownies to be a bit more moist on the inside. I baked them for about 30-35 minutes, so it might've been just a tad too long.

I took some of the reviewers' advice and let the pan simmer on low heat while melting the chocolate, and let the mixture cool down a bit before adding the eggs. I mixed everything thoroughly and I was amazed by the way the brownies rose in the oven. 

This recipe definitely is a keeper.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were really GREAT and everything I hoped for. I don't understand what others did to get cakey brownies but mine weren't like cake at all but very fudgy. I made them for the 2nd time last night and they were perfect. The 1st batch tasted good but the consistency was off. I felt it was something I did and no fault of the recipe. So the 2nd time around I did as other reviewers suggested and tempered the eggs and also left the pot on the stove (low heat) while melting the chocolate. I made sure to mix a lot better and longer the second time so that the batter was very smooth. My first batch was like others experienced - not done in the center and over done on the outside because I kept cooking to try and get the center done.  Whatever changes I made the second time around with mixing really well, tempered eggs or whatever, I didn't have the problem the second time. They cooked for exactly the 30 minutes and are fabulous.  I definitely want to try swirling peanut butter or adding pb chips the next time around. Will make these forever! These are also better for me than boxed (aside from the preservatives) because I am not supposed to have wheat and I can do my own thing.  For anyone else with that issue, I used organic soy flour and it worked perfectly.

They're soft, moist, and perfect! If I can do it, so can you (and my baking skills are zero LOL).

To fit the tastes of my husband and myself, I used a cup each of milk and white chocolate morsels in the mix. No more searching for a brownie recipe... I'm done. Thanks for enlightening me!!

text:
Initially three stars but upped to four because they became much better the second day. I was a little skeptical as I put it in the oven because there wasn't a lot of batter, but it rose. I liked that this recipe only had 2 tablespoons of butter and 1/2 cup of sugar. The brownies looked great, with a nice crisp top, and it only sunk a little as it cooled. They had a nice, fudge-y flavor that hit the spot. The batter itself wasn't too tasty - a little like baking soda - but maybe that was a good thing (: The brownies were great the next day, very chewy and chocolatey. I followed the recipe to a T.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I'm the kind of cook who would rather just eat the chocolate chips for my chocolate fix than cook the brownies, especially from scratch!  I've made plenty of brownies from mixes, though, and have always found them to be tastier than all the brownie recipes I've tried.  However, these were way easy to make and tasted great.  They aren't what I would consider chewy or fudgey, but not as cakey as most.  So a happy medium.  Put ice cream on top, and there is your 5 star dessert.  One pot to clean and the measuring cups go in the dishwasher, so it's an easy cleanup.  I'll definitely use this recipe again.

So! These were delectable, although I made some changes to make the recipe easier. When I was scraping the fudge mixture out of my saucepan into my mixing bowl, I put it back on the heat and added a little bit of water to make it easier to scrape out. And instead of mixing the dry ingredients beforehand, as I had no other mixing bowls, I sifted them first like I always do. I think that next time I make these, I will add a little bit of sugar. I found that they needed just a teensy bit more sweetness.

text:
I used Hershey’s Special dark chocolate chips because I prefer dark chocolate, and I took another reviewer’s suggestion and used strong coffee instead of a water.  I was worried because the chocolate chips did not entirely melt before the mixture stiffened up, but the unmelted bits turned into gooey little pockets of chocolate in the finished product.  First time ever making homemade brownies and I will never use a boxed mix again!  Great recipe and my go-to from now on.

This recipe was so easy to make and was a fabulous batch of brownies.  Everyone commented on how delicious they were. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
4th time is the charm!  I baked 4 recipes today.

1st: Brooke's Best Bombshell - decent, but intoxicatingly sweet. 
2nd: Best Brownies - meh, pretty bland..not cakey, not chewy, not brownie. 
3rd: Jocooks.com brownie recipe - too bold in chocolate flavor, bitter. 
4th (and last): Yep....this is the one.  I was about to give up on homemade brownies.  The differentiatior was definitely chocolate chips instead of cocoa.  Toffee like texture on outer edges and rich and cakey on the inside, but not as tender as a cake.  I love chocolate cake and I love brownies so I must be able to make a distinction between the two.  Try this recipe...don't let the name fool you!

text:
These brownies are both easy to make and exceptionally tasty (if you ever get the chance to eat one)!  I, personally, like 'softer, chewy' brownies, so I only cooked them for  25 minutes. My problem came afterwards in the 'cooling process.' How do you keep everyone away from beautiful brownies....Their smell just wafts throughout the house. If you are lucky enough to have leftovers for the next day - they are scrumptious and go especially well with coffee. 
Thank you for the easy, but magnificent recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious & satisfying brownies!
Living overseas, it was easier and less expensive to get dark bar chocolate [70% -85% cacao] than choc. chips.  
I estimated the grams of choc. bars needed based on a handy online guide found at--
http://cookitsimply.com/measurements/cups/chocolate-chips-0070-085q.html
In my tabletop oven they were done in 20 min. at 160 deg. C.  My brownies turned out a bit dry around the edges & cake-like, so next time I will try a shorter baking time or check my oven's temperature accuracy; and maybe increase the butter and chocolate a little.

text:
-update: made the recipe again using a mini muffin pan- I baked for 17 mins, but I think 15 mins might be perfect - also used whole wheat flour instead of AP and all brown sugar -

i halved the recipe and used a regular muffin pan to make 3 brownies (perfect for a smaller portion!). baked at 325 for 25 mins, but next time I think 22 mins will be perfect if you're looking for the dense fudgey brownies. Also i might cut down a tad bit on the flour next time so they wont be as cakey

None
text:
Excellent recipe. I made minimal changes: instead of butter I used Earth Balance vegan butter, and instead of AP flour I used King Arthur white whole wheat flour. I also used a 9x12 pan and baked for 24 minutes. The brownies are delicious: moist and very chocolate-y and with a pleasant crinkle top. They are a little crumbly and tend to fall apart when cut, even when cool. Next time I'll think about adding a 3 Tablespoons or so of tapioca flour and see if that makes them hold together better.

text:
Full disclosure I'm irritatingly hunting replacement for Betty Crock Orig Supr brownies.  So, that being said have made these brownies twice exactly per directions and they cook perfect, moist, light crust on top (always metal aluminum pan).  But I don't like the semi sweet flavor, too used to milk choc).  I think I'd like better with Milk Choc Chips but as a Brownie freak I only make 2 (13x9) pans at once for the crowds and that means 6 cups choc chips which is pricey and I have access to Semi Sweet in bulk bag not the Milk Choc I want to try.  I have let all friends try and I know they miss the milk choc flavor, they're a little too dark choc taste since it's soo many choc chips in recipe.  It's a good recipe, very smooth batter. Not a fan of "depth of flavor". It's a brownie! Ha Ha

My result was less brownie, and more cake squares ??. 
Everything looked perfect until edges started burning at 15min in the oven, so I lowered the heat to 300F and cooked it for 5 more min (inside was still gooey). Took it out of oven at 20min, and let it sit for 5min. Inside was no longer gooey! But bottom and edges were over cooked.

It still tasted great despite having a crumbly consistency and being super soft and spongey like cake. Gluten free is very hard to master.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I came across a half-bag of semisweet chocolate chips while organizing my pantry the other day. I didn't want to throw them away (they were Whole Food organic chocolate chips, so probably cost more than I should have paid), so I searched Allrecipes.com for a recipe in which I could use them. I decided to make these brownies after reading the great reviews, and am very glad I did.

As many other reviewers have noted, this recipe is super-easy - almost as simple as using a boxed mix. I followed it to the letter (incl. 25 min. baking time) and the brownies came out perfectly. I'm not even much of a brownies person, but will hang onto this recipe for future parties, housewarming gifts, etc. (I took them along when I went to pick up my husband after he played golf; they were a huge hit with the guys in the bar.)

text:
Delicious.  No changes.  My 4 year old made them... with a bit of help.  Easy recipe.  One pot.  Loved it!  Oh I guess I used less than a 1/2 cup of sugar.  We are reducing sugar in our diet and they were great with this reduction.  I think a person could even cut the sugar in half and they would still be fine.  Really, when using that much chocolate chips, you won't need as much sugar.  I would likely find them too sweet if I used all the sugar but, that is personal preference.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3672764.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
There are so many 4.5-star rated recipes it was really kind of hard to pick one and go with it. I wanted to do things right, and by that I mean I wanted to make sure I picked a recipe that would have the right amount of sweetness but not be overpowering and full of sugar. This recipe seemed to fit the bill. The chocolate isn't super rich (surprisingly, actually) and the sweetness is definitely toned down. But it's a huge hit with my kids and my wife who are really picky about things like that. This recipe was very easy to make and it doesn't take long. I cooked them for 27 minutes. I think I could have gotten away with one or two more minutes, as the very bottom of the very center was still just a little moist. But overall, these came out perfect!

Just wanted to say I made these today.  While the batch it makes is very small, the flavor and texture is beautiful.  I was out of liquid vegetable oil so I used vegetable shortening and just melted it in the microwave.  Also, there are two diabetics in my household so I used stevia powder instead of sugar.  They are marvelous still with the substitutions.  My diabetic family members swear its as close to "the real thing" sugar-wise as they've ever gotten.  Next time I'll have to adjust the stevia amount though as its much sweeter than sugar so they are overly sweet.  My fault not the fault of the recipe!

region:

country:
None
text:
Best. Brownies. Ever. I make them in a 4 cup Pyrex measuring cup, microwaving the butter, water, sugar, & chocolate chips for 30 seconds at a time until melted. I let it cool for 5 mins, then add the rest of the ingredients as per the instructions. Pour into a baking pan lined with foil & sprayed with coconut oil for easy cutting & clean up once they’re baked.

text:
I made it and it was easy and had a rich chocolate taste. The top cracked and I googled the reason. Apparently I over baked it, so it recommended to bake for less time. I baked the recipe a second time but we used a different brand of chip morsels and decreased the baking time, this turned out a less cracked top but the gooey fudge was gone and a more dry brownie baked up. So I’m going to try the same brand from the first time around and decrease the baking time, I’ll keep you all posted!

text:
I prefer dense, gooey, fudgy brownies. This was more of a fluffy, salty kind of brownie. The semisweet chips give it a different kind of flavor - not just straight rich chocolate.

In a second batch, I was able to get a richer, less salty flavor by using unsalted butter and bittersweet chips, but it still didn't have the gooey texture I want.

text:
I've made these multiple times; they are quick and always turn out great!  If you didn't have good results, try again.  Tip:  if using salted butter, don't add salt.  I always buy unsalted butter.  Check brownies often and know your oven.  Once when making two batches of these for different events I accidentally left 1/3 of a cup of flour out of one batch.  They still turned out good, just more fudgy which my family liked.  Both batches were very good!

text:
These were super easy to make and oh my so good to eat.  The only change i made was to add 1/2 cup chopped pecans because I like nuts in my brownies.  For those that had them crumble, if you let them cool completely before cutting you can avoid this problem.  I think my oven temperature is a bit off, so I had to cook 5 extra minutes.  Highly recommend these to avoid the box chemicals and because they are 100 times better than any box mix.  Tastes like something you get at a fancy bakery.

text:
Followed recipe exactly. Tasted good but I had a couple of the same issues as a number of the negative reviews. My chocolate seized as soon as I mixed with the butter syrup, I thought it may be because I poured the liquid over the chocolate in a glass bowl so maybe it was too cold to melt properly. A few rounds in the micro did not help so I tossed it (reluctantly) and tried again this time adding the chocolate into the warm pot of buttery sugar and still seized. I used some major elbow grease to try and mix in the eggs for a smooth texture...oh did I mention I had doubled the recipient based on all the positive reviews! The brownie puffed up very high in the oven but took 35 minutes to set enough to where there was no jiggle. Then the center totally fell and was almost a raw batter under a crusty top. The edges were nice and chewy though. Not sure this will get a second chance.

text:
Cautionary tale. I ruined this recipe by adding 1-2 Tablespoons of unauthorized brewed decaf. It turned the chocolate mixture into a non glossy paste and the chunks of that mixture took so much mixing to get them to incorporate into the flour that it brought out the glutens. The brownies tasted bad, and were tough and cake like with no satin top layer. Do not do.

text:
Fast brilliant brownie recipe. Semi sweet chips is a must, milk chocolate would make it too sweet, salt is always a must with chocolate. I would never modify a recipe I plan to review, as that wouldn't be an honest review, but I could see adding nuts or chocolate chunks before baking. Yum! I made the first batch as directed, so I could review it properly, but for the second one I microwaved the chocolate, butter and sugar  for expediency then mixed in the rest. Both methods worked and tasted the same. Great recipe, thanks for sharing!

Recipe is great. What's nice about it is that a mixer is not necessary. All you need is a spatula to mix the ingredients together. 

Used a muffin pan for the mixture. Greased the pan by using a paper towel and canola oil. Doesn't matter what kind of oil to use.

Will make it again. The texture of the brownie is cake-y. Probably because of the eggs.

text:
I made these to take to a friend's house for dinner. We all took a big bite, paused, and went, "wow. These are not good."

The only changes I made were:
1) I used dark chocolate féves instead of semisweet chips
2) I sprinkled some extra féves into the batter (as other reviewers mentioned doing)
3) I used a 6x8 pan.

I kept double and triple checking the ingredients and measurements bc there didn't seem to be anywhere near enough liquids, but they were so highly reviewed that I just went with it. They were truly awful. I'm assuming it was my error since they are so well-reviewed but I genuinely can't figure out where I  went wrong. They were salty, crumbled in the middle, dry, bitter. Honestly and truly the worst brownies I've ever tasted. If someone can figure out my mistake, please post it!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These had a very gooey texture. I don't understand how some people here can have really fudgy brownies while others complain they were too dry and cakey. I guess it's all in the cooking time. 

But I cooked them for 25 min and they were still undone in the center so I let them go another 5 minutes and the top was almost burned and the middle was still gooey. After they cooled the texture was fine (except for the extra crispy top), but the taste was nothing to write home about.

Also the chocolate seized when adding to the hot liquid but I saved it by keeping calm, whipping the heck out of it and carrying on. 

The worst part: way too salty. I knew better but I wanted to follow the recipe. Might try these again using what I've learned to tweak if all I have are chocolate chips in the house.

text:
UPDATE:
Okay, so we just made the adjusted brownies. Definitely much fudgier and flatter without the second egg. We agreed, my partner needs to increase the bake time by about five minutes but overall a super fudgey brownie. Extremely rich and gooey so these may not be for you the way we adjusted them. Next will be a batch with cinnamon and a batch with coffee. Before the update...first time making them: OMG!!!!!!! Probably THE best brownie recipe we have found yet. For a few years now we have been trying to find a non-mix or box replacement that we could make from scratch. This is IT!!
Tried this recipe the other night and other than the fact that they came out a bit cakier than we like, they were fantastic. Tonight we are making them again with only one egg and a mix of Hershey's and Ghirardelli Chocolates. We are hoping using one less egg will make them fudgier and flatter. Fingers crossed.
All in all a great brownie recipe.

text:
The first time I made this I baked it for exactly 25 minutes because of all the reviews saying not to overcook it.  It came out very fudgy and gooey.  It also fell in the middle. I ended up throwing that batch away.  I tried the recipe again but baked it for 35 minutes and it came out perfect for us.  At 35 minutes the brownies are more on the cake-like side and the toothpick inserted in the center came out clean.  I added 1/2 cup of pecans and crumbled bacon to the second batch.  My husband loves them.

I doubled the recipe and baked in 9X13 pan. I made with Ghiradelli bittersweet chocolate. I used brewed coffee for the water and, of course, I cut the salt by half !
I loved the ease of making these brownies. Only 1 saucepan, a whisk and a spatula were needed. It took 10 minutes of prep and about 35 minutes of baking (double recipe). Now, the best part was biting into a piece of these  chocolaty, chewy goodness..Be warned, it will be hard to stop at 1 piece !

text:
I made 24 servings of these as the recipe called for. They were great! Not too dry not too greasy. The only thing I would change is the chocolate chips. The recipe calls for semi sweet chips and I find those some what bitter. I made them and they were sweet enough but to really top it off next time I plan to use half semi sweet half milk chocolate chips. Easy to bake easy to cut. They had a good texture and nice light  layer on the top. I used a 9x13 pan with cooking paper instead of foil or grease. Definitely plan to make these again!

text:
This recipe is Excellent!! I will never make brownies from a box again! My hubby is a diabetic but he still enjoys a sweet treat now and then so when I bake for him, I use Splenda in place of sugar. My 3 yr old grand daughter & I made a triple batch this morning! I used Splenda in place of the sugar and also omitted 1/4 c (figuring the chocolate chips would be plenty sweet) and also omitted some of the salt (only used 1 1/8 teaspoon for our triple batch).  Our brownies turned out EXCELLENT & my grand daughter was very proud of herself ;)
The texture of the brownies is perfect and better than a box mix. I have to say, using semi sweet chocolate chips is so much easier and better than using cocoa powder! Thank you so much for sharing your recipe! It is definitely a keeper and will be made often in our home.

text:
I made these today following directions exactly, but in the end added some chopped  walnuts. The pan turned out yummy and cake like. Had the brownies been more fudgey and chewy (my preference) I would have given 5 stars instead of 4. I don't know if it's my oven but they were done in 19 minutes and came out moist. The flavor is intense chocolate and way better than using the cocoa powder. I was concerned the eggs would scramble when I added them to the fudge but they didn't. I can't eat a brownie without nuts so added the walnuts in at the very end and it worked perfectly. Will be making these again since I always have all the ingredients in my cupboard.

text:
I have never made brownies before and was so pleased with how this turned out.  The brownies were very moist with a wonderful chocolate flavor and while they are decadent i did not think they were overly sweet. Secondly, while i didn't read every review i was surprised that no one added peanut butter. I would strongly advise adding this. I added two heaping tablespoons of chunky pb and baked 25 minutes and these turned out scrumptious. This recipe is  definitely a keeper. I think the next time  i will pair this with raspberry sauce drizzled over a good vanilla ice cream mm give me some.

Yum yum yum! These are perfectly fudgy, chewy brownies with the classic "crackle top". WAY too much salt in this recipe though (and I love salted sweets). If using salted butter, I would omit the salt or at MOST do a 1/4 tsp. I generally use salted butter so next time I will leave out the the salt.

text:
Super tasty brownie! You don't get the powder chunks like you often do with powdered cocoa. I used 4 tbs of butter to melt the chocolate chips instead of the water. I added about a half cup of chocolate chips into the batter. I like the little globs of chocolate. I also used a small cookie sheet to bake them. It only takes 20 minutes...and it's good if you need a bunch of small brownies. I will absolutely use this as my go to brownie recipe.

userID:
5757615
Display Name:
lilorchid82
isPro:

5

170
favoritesCount:
448
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is peculiar b/c it only calls for 2 tbn of butter and you  boil the butter/water/sugar mixture.  I don't know what the purpose of this is, but the recipe was definitely not lacking. My husband loves chewy brownies.  Like extremely dense and chewy.  I did a little googling (I don't know how the world functioned before the internet...was that what they called the Dark Ages?) and found out that that for optimal chew you need to use less egg (so I did one large egg and one egg yolk), no baking soda, banged the pan on the counter (to release the trapped air), and chilled in the fridge for an hour after baking.  and since I used a pyrex dish, I made sure to line it with buttered aluminum before adding the batter, so that I could simply lift the brownie out to cool after baking and prevent the retained heat in the pyrex from overcooking my brownies.  I cut after the brownies had chilled, and it was similar to the texture of those "love and quiches" brownies I used to get complimentary on flights...if not denser.  

I've tried many of the best recipes on this site, and so far this one is the best.  Crazy that it is also one of the simplest and (relatively) healthiest.  In the future, I want to try the recipe again with 1/4 tsn salt, 1 tsn vanilla, and 1/2 a.p. flour.  That last alteration should make the brownies even denser.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-11-01T08:32:01.16

country:
None
text:
This is an amazing  recipe but I add baking powder instead of baking soda mainly because I think it makes them to salty, Instead of boiling the sugar,butter and water in a pan. I  do a double boiler and  fully mixed(I don't let it boil) then mix the chocolate and vanilla together then before the chocolate dries out  I add in the eggs and then the rest of the dry ingredients. 
Beside that they are the best brownies I have made at home, my whole family ask me to make them all the time.


 (side note have the eggs at room temp for 20-30 min before baking make the eggs fluff up in the batter)

text:
OMG THIS WAS THE MOST AMAZING RECIPE EVER!!!!!!!!!!! I've now made them dozens of times and every time they flew. Two tips--One, melt the butter a bit before mixing it in with the pan, and Two, mix in the chocolate over low heat, same with the egg mixture. It will make it smoother and easier to mix. And yes, don't over bake. Even if the brownies don't look done, they'll set more as they cool. And trust me, you want theses fudgy.

userID:

Display Name:
Tami Baity
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/516039.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are THE BEST brownies I have ever made.  I bake for a living from my home and made 2 double recipes of these as part of a dessert table.  People were falling over themselves they loved them so much.  I have made them many times since then and EVERYONE loves them. They have such a creamy yet fluffy texture.  I did not alter the recipe in any way, other than doubling it and baking it in a 9x13 pan.  Doing this, I baked at 325 F for 30 minutes.  DO NOT OVER BAKE!! 25 mins max for the 8x8 pan and single recipe.  30 mins max for the 9x13 double recipe.  Also, use good chocolate chips.  Ghirradelle (sp?) is my go to brand.  I used Hersheys once and they did not come out as good.  I was kicking myself for wanting to save $1.  This recipe, although harder than the mix of course, is not that difficult.  The result is brownies in a different stratosphere. Don't be deterred by the critics and belly ache-ers.  This recipe is legit!

If you guys are like me and don't like to wait for brownies and are also a neat freak, cut the brownies with a plastic knife.

text:
These brownies were delish! Everyone said they were the best brownies they ever had. I noticed that in other reviews, some people said that these brownies were bland, or was dry like chocolate cake. That would mean the cocoa they used was bland or that they overcooked them. If you use great quality cocoa and you don't cook it too long, these brownies taste insanely delicious!!! Try organic Cocao... makes them taste like chocolate truffles. We put them in cupcake tins and cooked for 20 mins, a little gummy the first day, but the next day after it was set, it was totally perfect!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Had a huge craving for brownies and did not have cocoa powder on hand so I was looking for a recipe using melted chocolate (as I had multiple bags of chocolate chips).  Followed this recipe exactly but used 2 cups of melted chocolate chips (1 cup bitter sweet & 1 cup semi-sweet as I like dark chocolate).  Had to bake this for about 20 min. more than recipe stated., but it was simply not done (I kept checking..)  These brownies were definitely rich & chocolately..not cake like at all, but not fudgy either..not sure if the extra 1/2 cup of chocolate I added made it less dense than it should be.  I was looking for a dense, fudgy consistency and mine came out softer than I like my brownies to be.  All in all it totally satisfied my brownie fix.  I added 1 cup chopped walnuts to batter also.  I would try this again and use only 1 1/2 c. melted chocolate. Very easy recipe!! Thanks for sharing!

These are terrific brownies.  Made mine in non-stick mini muffin pans (one recipe filled 36 mini cups) and reduced baking time to 15-20 minutes.  Moist on the inside, perfectly crisp around the edges.  Definitely the best homemade brownie recipe I have tried.  It's a keeper.

text:
My daughter picked this recipe to make for her brother's birthday ALL BY HERSELF (she's 11). It was easy and we had most of the ingredients. So I let her make them and only helped a little. They are super easy and they are homemade. No icky chemicals to ruin them. There was a lot of stirring involved and I needed to cook them the full 30 mins. But, other than them not really cutting well because they are cake-like, they turned out great! Very fudgy and you can press the crumbs together to make a whole other piece! We will definitely save this recipe and maybe play with it to come up with different flavor combos. Thank you for posting this. It was definitely what we were looking for.

text:
This was a respectable recipe.  I used Guittard chocolate chips and 1 cup of walnuts.  The texture was great; the actual flavor of the brownies was chocolate-y, but I have made many pans of brownies in my life, and I prefer the ones made with cocoa/oil, or unsweetened chocolate/butter.  Like another reviewer said, it could have been the lack of a stick of butter vs. 2 Tablespoons, I don't know.  But I like my recipe better for flavor.

text:
This recipe was easy to make but not my favorite. The flavors and texture are pretty pedestrian, but perfect for quick dessert for kids. The only problem I had was that the chocolate seized up on me when I added it to the hot butter. I had to dump the whole thing in the kitchen aid and beat to soften it. But once I did this, it was easy to spread in the pan and baked in exactly 25 minutes. I think upping the amount of butter would drastically improve the flavor and texture.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used only 1 1/4 cup of sugar. Just because I ran out, and they still came out very well. They came out very thick, and after an overnight cooling in my refrigerator,  they probably shrunk about only half an inch. The taste reminded me of a brownie, but it also had a little taste of Hot Chocolate.  They are very easy to make, and really wouldn't take more than a hour. If you do plan to make several batches in different saucepans,  I recommend staggering the times that you make it, because it seems that during the warming of the butter combination,  it might burn.  I would still recommend this to any begging to moderate baker.

Great, simple recipe. I made two batches- one as is and one with a cheesecake topping. Both came out delicious! I reduced the sugar to about 3/4 cup since the semi-sweet chocolate chips already has a sweetness to it and I didn't want mine to be overly sweet.  Definitely a keeper!

text:
OMG, I love these! I did a 50/50 mix of brown/white sugar and left out the salt completely which wasn't at all noticeable.  I whisked the eggs into the chocolate quickly so as to not cook them which worked a treat.  I doubled the recipe and divided the batter between 2 silicone 7"x7" pans.  For the benefit of the UK a tablespoon of butter is 15g.  Rather than chocolate drops I just chopped up 400g of dark chocolate bars (Morrisons saver bars believe it or not - use 200g for the recipe of which I doubled).  I don't think these are going to last 24hrs given that my family keep going back to the kitchen and coming back looking guilty!

text:
It's Valentine's Day and I decided to whip up a tasty dessert for the dinner I'm fixing for my hubby of 27 years.  We've been snowed in for a week, so I don't have much in the pantry in the way of baking products.  The one thing I did have was chocolate chips: semi-sweet, dark chocolate, milk chocolate.  I started searching for a brownie recipe I could make using chocolate chips (I've always used bakers chocolate). I found this recipe. I followed the recipe, but did use 1 cup semi-sweet and 1/2 cup special dark chocolate chips instead of all semi-sweet. It was quick to fix, tasty, and the perfect ending to my Valentine's dinner.  This one will go in my recipe box.

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe exactly like it says. It was very quick and easy. Wow and they came out amazing! I use Ghirardelli chocolate chips and I baked the brownies for about 28 minutes. The only difficulty I had was after I melted the chocolate chips. I was worried the eggs would cook if I put them in right away, so I let the chocolate mixture cool just a bit. It made it more difficult to mix in the eggs and vanilla after the chocolate had cooled and clumped, but after mixing for a few minutes it combined nicely. Overall, these brownies are amazing and very chocolatey! I will be making them again!

text:
I usually make brownies with cocoa powder but decided to try this recipe as I had a bunch of chocolate chips on hand. Wow these are amazing brownies, I can't stop eating them! I followed recipe exactly and baked in a glass pan for 25 minutes, they turned out crunchy on top and inside was chocolate fudgey goodness! They really don't need frosting either, in fact I'd say they are better without. This recipe is definitely a keeper.

Display Name:
ShannonWicks

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These brownies were pretty great! I had a taste for brownies but not many ingredients on hand, so I chose this recipe.  I decided to make one and a half times this recipe (I would have doubled it but didn't have enough sugar) before realizing I needed to make other modifications. I didn't have chocolate chips on hand, but I had: 4 oz. unsweetened chocolate squares & 4 tbsps brown sugar (ran out of white), & a combo of 9 tbsps cocoa, 7 tbsps brown sugar (still out of white), 3 tbsps shortening.  This was the equivalent of 10 oz. of chocolate chips, instead of the 9 oz. called for, but I love chocolate, so it worked for me.  

Even with the modifications, the brownies turned out really well, with 1 exception.  They were salty.  Because I made 1.5 times the recipe, I added 1.5 tsp of salt.  Perhaps I shouldn't have added that much, but next time, I won't add any at all.  I ended up making the brownie frosting from the "Best Brownies" recipe on this site to cut the salty taste, which helped.  Without the salt factor, I would've given 5 stars!!
Review:

text:
Loved these! Was having a serious craving and had no box mix in the house. Googled chocolate chip brownie recipes (because I had chips in the pantry!) and was able to whip these up in 5 minutes. I used the microwave to melt chips butter and water together. Took about a minute. Don't completely melt the chips. They will continue to melt after taking them out of
F the micro as you stir in sugar and vanilla. The whole recipe can be made in one bowl!

I am making them again today but will try to boost the chocolate factor by adding some cocoa powder. Loved these & won't go back to the box mixes!!!!

text:
I followed this recipe exactly, and the brownies came out fantastic! They were rich, moist, and delicious. I was worried that the brownies would be too small but they rose in the oven to a perfect size. You have to be careful not to overcook them by checking often with a toothpick, at the end mine didn't come out perfectly clean but with only a few spots. I would warn that the recipe really only yields 9 servings, unless you cut the brownies extremely small. My only complaint is that there isn't enough of them! These were a big hit, and I will be making these again. Don't change a single thing!

text:
Excellent recipe. The first time I made it, I ran out of semi-sweet and had to add 1/2 cu milk chocolate in order to reach the full 1 1/2 cups of chips. This ended up changing the consistency of it to more of a cake than a brownie, interestingly.  The second time I did it the correct way (with all semi-sweet chips) and it was perfect.

text:
Super simple and really, really good. The only change I made was to add a very small amount of corn syrup to keep the sugar from getting grainy (just a fail-safe I normally do), and I mixed in a few walnuts. If you prefer a gooey (as opposed to cakey) brownie, this is a no-fail recipe. (Stirring and butter amount can be a huge factor with cocoa powder recipes)

My husband and my son were VERY please.

I have a very similar recipe [same ingredients but measurements are slightly different] and I adore making these brownies. It is so easy that I never use brownie mixes in a box.  I like to add half the bag of chocolate chips and stir them until melted and then add the remaining half of the chocolate chips before pouring the batter into the 8 x 8 pan.
